title: Part 1
content:
Part 1

I EXITED THE gate, had the car pulled up to the front entrance, and quickly headed to the guest room.

Sakayanagi, who had been standing and looking out the window rather than sitting on the sofa, turned around.

"Sorry to keep you waiting."

"It's no problem, Ayanokouji-sensei. I arrived earlier than scheduled."

Sakayanagi, bowing politely, approached with his usual smile.

"I was looking forward to the White Room's unveiling today."

"That seems to be the case."

Over the past three years, I continued to strengthen my ties with Sakayanagi.

I thought we were incompatible due to his privileged upbringing—well, in fact, we probably didn't get along. However, even so, people can become unpredictable when a common goal is present.

Perhaps because I had dealt with people always probing for ulterior motives, meeting with Sakayanagi, who had no hidden agendas, had become a relief rather than a pain.

"Still, I was surprised by the security. It doesn't seem to fit this place."

"It can't be helped. We can't make this public right now. There are countless people desperately searching for scandals involving me and Naoe-sensei."

Sakayanagi just gave a wry smile, perhaps troubled by my response.

"You were the one who helped with the White Room project the most. I wanted to show it to you first."

"I just wanted to support this project since more children would be saved."

Sakayanagi firmly believed that these children would carry Japan's future.

For Naoe-sensei and me, it was merely a card used to promote ourselves, but that idea had already been taken into consideration.

Whatever his motives, if this plan saved children, he would approve.

He was an incorrigibly good person, but because of that, it was hard to tell when he might've become an enemy.

If he were to realize that the children's futures weren't guaranteed, he would distance himself from me.

"Let me guide you."

"Please do."

I first led Sakayanagi to the laboratory.

"Today is an important day to decide on a new policy for the White Room, and I want you to see the children's growth."

"The children we took in are already over three years old, aren't they? Time sure flies."

Sakayanagi, being a collaborator, also saw some of the children.

He must've recalled several past scenarios.

"Aren't you going to have children?"

When I met Sakayanagi, he already had a partner he had been with for several years.

I hadn't heard of any current pregnancies or children.

"It's not that I don't want them, but we just haven't been blessed with the opportunity. We've agreed to leave it to nature."

In other words, even if there was a problem with either the husband, wife, or both, he chose to avoid touching upon it.

As long as they're both satisfied, it isn't a bad choice.

"I see. I spoke out of turn, forget I said anything."

"I've always been curious, but aren't you going to get married, Ayanokouji-sensei?"

"I might consider it if I had someone, but unfortunately, I've been single for a while now. No plans either."

"Having a partner is essential for continuing a long political career. I hope you find someone soon, Ayanokouji-sensei."

"That would be nice."

Love, marriage, childbirth—I have no time for such things.

They say people become stronger when they have someone to protect, but unfortunately, I don't think so.

Having someone to protect also meant having a weakness.

I had seen many politicians fall for the sake of those they protected.
